featuredReview.headline: Software test Engineer
featuredReview.pros: Compensation and benefits are good and better than the competitors.
featuredReview.cons: Work/Life balance is not so good

featuredReview.headline: Great company
featuredReview.pros: Basically a massively managed start up. You can easily swap positions within the structure to do what you're passionate about.
featuredReview.cons: Not much to say negatively at this point. One of the best jobs to land around San Diego to grow your technical knowledge

featuredReview.headline: A company that cares
featuredReview.pros: Fun, steady work. Great culture
featuredReview.cons: sometimes you don't get the recognition you deserve

featuredReview.headline: A Nice Experience
featuredReview.pros:
Employee exchange program that can allow you to explore working for Sony in other parts of the world
Learning Japanese culture
In my team, we had a lot of room to choose our own technology
See what it takes to affect change in a incredibly large company
Great work life balance in America (not so good in Japan)
You meet a lot of different people
featuredReview.cons:
Advancement doesn't seem to be based on technological merit or performance, but more on sticking to how Sony already does things
Management on both sides of the Pacific don't seem to be in sync most of the time

featuredReview.headline: Software Engineer
featuredReview.pros: New Technology.  Work on the whole cycle of a project including design, implement and testing.
featuredReview.cons: Management sometimes listens to people who talks the idea but not implements it.

featuredReview.headline: Amazing Company
featuredReview.pros:
Really awesome work environment
Amazingly smart people
Every good work is appreciated
featuredReview.cons:
Newer technology adoption is slower
Compensation is lagging behind competitors

featuredReview.headline: The Active Ship Isn't Sinking.  It Already Sank.
featuredReview.pros:
ActiveX program encourages a healthy lifestyle
Mid-level managers are empathetic to employees
Salaries and benefits are decent
Job is located in San Diego
Flexible work hours
featuredReview.cons:
I'll share what I wrote for my exit survey:
4. What triggered your decision to leave ACTIVE?

1) Executives hiding behind an NDA so that they don't have to tell employees about company plans.  Good news is shared.  Only bad news is "hidden", though they do a poor job of hiding anything -- everyone hears the leaks and knows about the plans.
2) Developers showing up from China unannounced to take over work from US-based teams.  This is the most bone-headed move I have ever seen in my years as an engineer.  Fear does not drive performance.  Nobody is going to stick around when there is a chance that they could instantly be replaced by a team from China.
3) Comments that can only be described as completely idiotic, made by the CEO during company-wide briefings.  "Look to your left, look to your right, one of them isn't going to be working here any more".  These comments do nothing to build employee trust in the leadership or the direction of the company, and they made my job as a manager even more difficult.
4) Replacement of San Diego-based skilled engineers with "senior engineers" in China who might be cheaper but are completely unqualified to be working on enterprise software systems.  I interviewed a couple of these folks, and the office manager in China even told me that I "had" to hire one of them.  If I "had" to hire one of them, why did I waste my time on the interview?
5) Failure by the management to identify critical employees and retain them, and to hire replacements for engineers who have left.  One of my teams once had 7 engineers; now we only have 2.  This is a team that is mission critical.  The team is now down to two relatively junior to mid-level engineers.
6) Failure on the executives' part to recognize that highly skilled and highly experienced people are working under them.  Active is not the military, and nobody here enjoys taking orders.  The last straw for me was having the R&D metrics forced upon myself and my teams, with no chance to provide feedback.  I ultimately saw that there was zero chance of being able to perform well under this system, which changed the calculus for me remaining here vs. moving to a new position elsewhere.

I'd like to be clear: most people, and most managers at this company are highly skilled, experienced and capable.  It's the people at the very top - the executives - that have brought this ship down.

featuredReview.headline: A lesson on how not to compete in the tech world
featuredReview.pros: Great work life balance. There are so few tech companies (particularly global corporations) that care enough about their employees home life as to encourage weekends off.  401K matching was terrific as well and the medical/dental benefits were top rate until the last year. Working with the latest in wireless technologies, software and test equipment.   Great co-workers whom not only know and ply their trade effectively but couldn't care less about office politics..
featuredReview.cons: Decisions by upper management and executives... yes, this is gripe often heard in the corporate world. However, when you go from one "burning platform" and jump head long into another "burning platform" (ie Windows Phone) it became a more steady decline.  The Metro UI of Windows 7 and 8 is unique, but hardly a favorite among mobile phone users. The early death of the Microsoft Kin mobile phone should have rang alarm bells.... not to mention the fact that Windows 7 devices couldn't be upgraded to 8, and the lack of apps (which should have been tackled early on)..

featuredReview.headline: Software Engineer - Great work life balance
featuredReview.pros:
Interesting projects.  Feel like you are making a difference in the world.
In-house training on a variety of technical and intelligence topics.  
Occasional cash bonuses to pursue technical certifications.   
Positive team dynamics  on most (but not all) project teams.  
Transparent raise & promotion process.  Yearly performance reviews.
Opportunity to move around among projects & roles.  
Informal team gatherings at happy hours, lunches etc.  
Supportive work environment leading to better project outcomes.
Employee volunteer days are lots of fun and benefit the local community.
You can probably make more money elsewhere but over the years I've seen several engineers leave for more $$ and then return in a year or two for the work life balance and lower stress atmosphere.
The positive team dynamics help engineers to excel.  Because engineers tend to stay for years, there's a willingness to invest and train.  Teamwork is valued highly and included in yearly reviews.
9/80 schedule with off Fridays.  
Occasional paid overtime.
Good retention rates allow long term working relationships to develop.
featuredReview.cons:
Declining benefits over the years: no more pension, fewer holidays, weaker health plan, shorter performance review process.  
Use of the lowest bidder to manage some company programs leads to less ideal service. 
No free food.

featuredReview.headline: Good company, smart and helpful people
featuredReview.pros:
Work with extremely smart people.
Everyone is willing to help.
Amazing work-life balance.
Lots of support.
featuredReview.cons:
Pay is barely competitive.
Seem to be falling behind as a big data company.

featuredReview.headline: Decent
featuredReview.pros: Lots of freedom, kind of slow paced if you like that.
featuredReview.cons: Kind of slow and not super coding intensive.

featuredReview.headline: Software Engineer IV
featuredReview.pros: Dependable business.  Job security.
featuredReview.cons: Depends on which group you are in and who your boss are, you get treated differently.  Some manager don't care, some gives salary based on favortism.  You can see people walking around, doing less work than you and make more money, because they got hired at a higher salary level.  This place never fire anyone.  so everyone who got locked in at a good salary stays. HR will negotiate salary if you find a higher paying job.

featuredReview.headline: It was great learning experience at HP's R&D labs
featuredReview.pros: Tried new and disruptive ways to do business by using latest trends in technologies
featuredReview.cons: Need to think long term and ahead of others.

featuredReview.headline: Great Company
featuredReview.pros: Many of the employees have been with the company for the company for a long time and are loyal to each other and loyal to team work.
featuredReview.cons: The overall company culture did change a bit after going public.

featuredReview.headline: Software
featuredReview.pros: Easy to get the job Done
featuredReview.cons: No learning opportunities but good for working

featuredReview.headline: Not living up to its potential
featuredReview.pros: The Sony PlayStation network is huge network, presenting many challenging engineering problems.  Coworkers are a great bunch of people who, while very diverse, get along well and are respectful of each other.  There’s always a fun social event to participate in.  Benefits are pretty good (I don’t know what other companies are offering but I’ve been happy with the benefits).
featuredReview.cons: Over the past three years, the San Diego office has seen a new senior VP, two additional VPs, multiple directors and senior architects and managers all come in from the same company (Intuit).  At the same time, the existing senior Sony people have been squeezed out, quietly encouraged to leave, or just fired.  No one from the original Sony Network San Diego in any position of responsibility and no one from the original Sony days has been promoted.  There have been many new senior level positions filled, but none from within the company.  Some have been given new titles, but no real promotions.  Existing engineers have not been allowed to participate in the technical direction of the network.  They are seen as hindrances and not as contributors.  A closed environment of fear and distrust has been created where people cannot question direction or voice honest opinions.  It’s a dreary engineering environment lacking in excitement or peer collaboration.

featuredReview.headline: Enterprise software "Security" product  that is made in China. What a joke!
featuredReview.pros: IT Security market is a good space to be.
featuredReview.cons:
Almost all R&D has been out sourced to communist China.  
Cheap and cutting costs by forcing out the people who could make the software work and won't hire anyone with the experience to fill that gap.
Low moral, depressing and very negative place.
Lack of leadership or vision.
This Company is bad for your career and self esteem.

featuredReview.headline: Sr. Software Engineer
featuredReview.pros: Broadcom remains a high growth company after the merger with Avago.
featuredReview.cons: Merger with Avago has resulted in a lot of layoffs.

featuredReview.headline: Minor growing pains but great company
featuredReview.pros: Very supportive of learning and pursuing what is interesting to you
featuredReview.cons:
Typical large corporate structure starting to slow down flexibility
Communication between groups is getting better but needs work

featuredReview.headline: Good people.  Bad Executives and Business Model.
featuredReview.pros: I've made long lasting relationships and friendships.  Non managers were awesome at their jobs.  There was a nice park across the street.
featuredReview.cons: Toxic executive and management.  Unethical business practices.  The company treats employees like commodities that are replaceable.

featuredReview.headline: Software Intern
featuredReview.pros:
Great people and culture
Relaxed enviroment
featuredReview.cons: Gets boring and slow at times

featuredReview.headline: Great Place to Work, Struggling to Remain Relevant
featuredReview.pros: Probably the most friendly company I have ever worked for. My team there was the best. That was the main reason I stayed for nearly 6 years.
featuredReview.cons: My recent "Reduction in Force" layoff seemed impulsive. The company has had lots of problems over the last 3 years. I don't think management can focus on a firm direction.

featuredReview.headline: Good company
featuredReview.pros: Work is challenging but never dull. Was quickly given the right amount of freedom to make important decisions. Teams self-organized and always improving. Family feeling to ownership and great work/life balance. Pay was good and raises happened on yearly basis. HR/timesheet system was better than other contractors I have worked for although still not great.
featuredReview.cons: Commercial leadership products being developed seemed to split the company into two pieces: (those who believed and those that did not).

featuredReview.headline: Sr Software Engineer
featuredReview.pros: Flexible working hours, Open door policy, good co workers
featuredReview.cons: No communication from management, no work life balance

featuredReview.headline: Got the job!
featuredReview.pros: I was contacted by Insight Global about a position they were trying to fill and that fit my resume and online profile.  The recruiter I worked with (Kory) was very courteous, friendly and prompt.  Working with her team I went in for an interview within a week and then was eventually considered for a better/higher position which I interviewed for several weeks later.  I really enjoyed working with the insight global team, they were very supportive and gave good advice on salary, contract to hire rates etc. that ended up getting me the best possible outcome: full time job, great salary, and good timeline for transition.  There were no surprises for the hiring company because Kory did a great job of communicating all the important issues up front.
featuredReview.cons: I did not have any negative experiences while being recruited by Insight Global. I really cannot thing of anything they could have done better except perhaps called me last year  :-)

featuredReview.headline: No work life balance. New Upper Management is trying to get rid of full time employees to bring on their favorite vendor
featuredReview.pros: None anymore. culture used to be very good and there were some talent.
featuredReview.cons: Constant micro management by upper management and giving no respect to their employees. Specificly asked to work overtime each week. Moral over all is very low, Company does not care about their employees anymore.

featuredReview.headline: Software qa engineer
featuredReview.pros:
Great fun environment while i was working there 2006-2008. New strong technology to learn, smart engineers
Lots of perks
featuredReview.cons: Changes after i have left and company bought out few times

featuredReview.headline: Love it
featuredReview.pros: Mindtouch is full of intelligent, positive people who really believe in the product and want to make it the best it can be. The culture fosters learning, growth, and fun.
featuredReview.cons: The only con I can think of doesn't really apply to me. Since the location is down town the parking situation isn't great but MindTouch reimburses its employees for a monthly trolley pass so I don't need to worry about it.

featuredReview.headline: Empowr is a great company to work for!
featuredReview.pros: I feel appreciated here. I feel like they treat me like I work here for 10 years and I'm here only 6 months. Everything is just functional, the teams work great together and there are some really talented guys here. I'm excited about the future. The management is always caring and doesn't put too much pressure on us.
featuredReview.cons: Some of the colleagues are dividing and don't feel that they are part of the whole organization. This could be fixed though.

featuredReview.headline: Software Engineer Intern
featuredReview.pros: Helpful mentor and manager, in a nice quiet location, friendly people, free snacks everyday, gym on location
featuredReview.cons: Only five interns, not a big company because it's a small division

featuredReview.headline: This place is awesome!
featuredReview.pros:
Working at Brightscope, you'll find yourself surrounded by people who are incredibly motivated, talented and  smart - the office is open, which fosters an atmosphere of camaraderie and collaboration.  The work is also challenging and engaging.

The company is growing and doing well, and the excitement of playing for a winning team is contagious.  The senior management have created a culture of transparency, and there's a monthly team meeting where anyone can bring any question to the table, which really helps clarify how the work that you're doing fits into the overall company strategy which is rewarding and motivating.

The pace is fast, but people are always willing to lend a helping hand.
featuredReview.cons: Brightscope isn't a place where you're going to be able to slip through the cracks - expect to work hard.  The good news is you're probably going to like what you're doing.

featuredReview.headline: Good Company to work for, but not best Culture/Environment
featuredReview.pros: Good interesting projects to work on and working and living in La Jolla is a good pro. My manager and team was really helpful and great people to work with. Good work schedule
featuredReview.cons: Sometimes it is necessary to work in small confined spaces with no windows. Also the work culture doesn't make you feel too welcomed. I wished there were more people my age group. There are a lot of older folk.

featuredReview.headline: A nice place to be
featuredReview.pros: Opinions are heard and valued, even if not acted on. The responsibility you take up becomes the role you fill, there are no artificial limits to your ability to contribute. A growing culture of curiosity.
featuredReview.cons: Many positive changes are happening, though they may appear slowly since the companies products are in world wide production.

featuredReview.headline: Absolutely zero organization
featuredReview.pros: The company pays well enough and treats their employees well.
featuredReview.cons: Management extremely disorganized and does not set cohesive goals. Employees are promoted exclusively on seniority, not skill level.

featuredReview.headline: Software Developer 3
featuredReview.pros: Love it, is great, great management
featuredReview.cons: Company that is not fully dedicated to software developer

featuredReview.headline: Fun fun fun... (And yes, also work)
featuredReview.pros: One of the best things about being at QualiTest is that our office in San Diego is like a big family; everyone is generally very friendly and helpful. We are even going together every morning to the Cross-fit (A membership the is fully covered by QualiTest. Isn't that great !!)
featuredReview.cons: Don't have anything yet... I hope I never will.

featuredReview.headline: A great place to slow down.
featuredReview.pros:
Flexible working hours.
Good 401k.
Relatively good paycheck.
featuredReview.cons:
Not much room for growth.
Not good for engineers, a lot of processes that kill or slow down creativity.
Not enough good leaders and engineers.
No bonuses or perks unless you are high in organization chart.

featuredReview.headline: Read this if you are joining the Healthcare Informatics Division
featuredReview.pros: I have been Resmed for about 5 years now working as a software engineer in the Healthcare Informatics division. They have one of the best campuses and the building is full of expensive art. They pay me well and I don’t have much to complain about as far as compensation and benefits. They have a gym onsite and good health programs which show their commitment to employee welfare. The senior management is progressive and we are set for a period of huge growth over the next few years.
featuredReview.cons:
As you can see they have a good overall structure in place to make it a great place to work. However that is where all the pros end. They are hiring a lot of people at this point and it's important that you read this review before you make a decision on joining the HI division. 

So it turns out we acquired a little mom-and-pop shop from Halifax and the overlords from that company are currently in the process of taking over the Healthcare Informatics division. There is rampant cronyism and the CEO of the mom-and-pop shop that has taken over us is busy promoting his own clueless incompetent people since the last 1 year or so. People who know very little about technology have gone from being first-line supervisors to Directors within a period of 6 months to a year. All this would be easy to ignore if this new management were fair or smart or knew what they were doing. People who were smart, understood business and technology and had big ideas have been turned into puppets of the new management. These new managers chill all dissent and punish people whose opinions they don’t like by sidelining them, demoting them or creating an environment in which people are forced to leave. The company has hired experts in many areas in the last couple of years but these experts are completely ignored and sidelined and eventually let go because their views don’t match with the clueless incompetent managers, leads and directors that work in the HI division. So if you are the type of person who has ideas and interest in changing things then this is absolutely one of the worst place to come to. These are things you should seriously consider because it is extremely frustrating and insecure to work here.

featuredReview.headline: Overall a good work experience
featuredReview.pros: The people there, both colleagues and managers, are really nice and incredibly helpful.  My boss fell into the category of "harsh but fair", which I think was something I needed at the time.  Plus, the overall work environment (office space, development practices, snacks, etc) is quite nice.
featuredReview.cons: The product itself is honestly rather boring, but more importantly, since it has all been developed already you almost never find yourself developing NEW code and features.  Instead you are assigned to work on one small part of the code base, and you only end up adding one or two lines.  I personally like to do more, so this was a problem for me.

featuredReview.headline: After Four years...
featuredReview.pros: Good management team, positioning company as a growth company.
featuredReview.cons: Slow growth, not so great compensation

featuredReview.headline: good company to learn and grow on SQL and BI technology
featuredReview.pros: Excellent company , very big direct clients and work environment is awesome.
featuredReview.cons: difficult to find any thing

featuredReview.headline: Software Test Engineer II
featuredReview.pros: The work culture is really good, not too much of stress at work. People are friendly and helpful. Scope to learn new technology
featuredReview.cons: Parking space is less, they are working on it to improve.

featuredReview.headline: Great place to work, not the best location.
featuredReview.pros:
Fun, friendly culture.
Competitive pay.
Work is challenging but pleasurable.
Flexible hours. 
Most work weeks are 40 hours. 
Plenty of parking.
Location feels safe. 
Employees treated to snacks and a game room.
Occasionally employees are treated to lunch/breakfast. 
Company appears to be performing well.
featuredReview.cons:
Advancement only possible at different company.
Location difficult to access during high traffic conditions.
Not many lunch options close by.
Language management uses is unprofessional and a liability. 
Product education software is virtually unusable. 
There is no technical documentation (API) on the main product the company produces.

featuredReview.headline: Stable Company
featuredReview.pros: They are a stable company with decent benefits.  Generally good profit sharing. Challenging and rewarding work.  Global company.  You can transfer almost anywhere in the world.
featuredReview.cons: Working for a remote site however, we do not get many of the benefits we would being at headquarters, like the advantage of training classes hosted there, and facilities such as gyms, ect.

featuredReview.headline: Management
featuredReview.pros: Great people. Hard workers.  The company really cares about the public and keeping them safe.
featuredReview.cons: To many distractions.  Run like we were putting out fires.  Too many silos.  Too much blame.

featuredReview.headline: Experience at Cardinal Health
featuredReview.pros: Very professional yet relax work environment. The interview process was somewhat taxing but it gave me confidence that I would be working with a very talented team.
featuredReview.cons: As with many large companies, there is a very mechanical career path for employees which seemed to frustrate some of the more ambitious software engineers hired directly out of college.

featuredReview.headline: Nice People Who Are Too Accepting Of Mediocrity And Nepotism
featuredReview.pros: The expectations are very low and you'll often be play testing games. Most people are very nice.
featuredReview.cons:
Game team leadership has an abundance of arrogance and elitism.
Game teams hire their friends and ignore talent from other departments.
Compensation is well below market.
No stock options or grants.
No opportunity for advancement (no one is let go for poor performance).
It's easy to pick up bad habits as management resists change.
With little to no coding standards, the game code is a mess.
The company is continuing to downsize as players leave EQ and EQII.
Significant use of contractors.

featuredReview.headline: Excellent
featuredReview.pros: Awesome company with great work-life balance, proper agile development, data-driven decision making and a fridge full of local beer.
featuredReview.cons: Every future company will disappoint after working here.

featuredReview.headline: Sr Embedded Software Engineer
featuredReview.pros: Great benefits. Large company. Lots of opportunities for management. Clear focus on ubiquitous computing, i.e. cloud computing after Satya Nadella took over.
featuredReview.cons: Work-life balance absent. Long hours, code bureaucracy (ownership). Based on Satya Nadella's new focus on cloud computing, embedded software focus diminished.

featuredReview.headline: Stay away
featuredReview.pros: Free lunch, nice building and stocked kitchen so you don't have to leave building.
featuredReview.cons:
This is probably the worst company I had ever worked for.  They do track the front door.  Despite all the people I worked with having favorable reviews of my performance the CBO gave or someone gave me notice less than 45 days after I started.

This is a company so poorly run that you could throw any amount of money there way and they couldn't build a paper towel holder.  Horrible management horrible company.

featuredReview.headline: Good Company.  Easy to get lost in the shuffle in such a large company.
featuredReview.pros: Great work life balance.  9-80 Work week is awesome.
featuredReview.cons: Large Company.  Decisions make out side of your view have major impacts on your work.

featuredReview.headline: Stable company
featuredReview.pros: Excellent pay/benefits; nice physical workplace; lots of long-term employees; large and varied code base; HR is helpful and professional; stable and regular income stream from customers; interesting and inspiring goals.
featuredReview.cons: Lack of clear direction to employees; long-simmering personal conflicts; some long-standing and deeply buried architectural flaws.

featuredReview.headline: Senior Software engineer
featuredReview.pros: nice office, decent working equipment,
featuredReview.cons: huge technical debt, inexperienced management

featuredReview.headline: Great people and exciting new areas to work
featuredReview.pros: Solute is full of good people who are trying to do cool things. The company is moving in the right direction and have people in charge who know what they are doing. They are trying to expand into new areas and provide innovation services. Being a small company, there is a benefit of getting your hands into different areas, which provides personal career growth.
featuredReview.cons: Being a small company, sometimes there is a lot to do for each person, but this is expected.

featuredReview.headline: Good company, friendly people,
featuredReview.pros:
* Hourly employees have a good rate
* The health benefits are great, even as an hourly employee, the company provided a fairly good portion of the expense.
* flexible hours, ability to telecommute depending on the project.
* shower facilities, I would use these quite often, especially for nearby pickup basketball games.
* possibility to work on multiple projects.
* food; stocked kitchen ( free drinks, snacks ) and monthly culinary events.
featuredReview.cons:
* it's an engineering services firm, so you have to come to grips that the current project may end and you'll be left without work that you can not bill and might be temporarily left go.  As a plus, if work does happen to spring up again, they may call you back.
* no 401k matching, but they do provide annual profit sharing based on your working hours throughout the year.
* There is a sense that sometimes the company isn't doing too well in finding more projects.

featuredReview.headline: It has been a very humble and positive experience.
featuredReview.pros: It is rite by the water.  In project, most of the people are nice and easy going.  Very good at making me feel like I am part of the team.
featuredReview.cons: Agile development is quite hard to accomplish with the internal and external bureaucracy that goes on in a government-funded project.

featuredReview.headline: Good place to work
featuredReview.pros: Professional Management, Good HR policies, Easy to reach out to.
featuredReview.cons: Pays can be made more competitive.

featuredReview.headline: ok
featuredReview.pros: Pretty stable, little risk of layoffs. But at the same time, not very exciting. Think of them as a CD or savings bonds of employment - They don't pay very well, but they're safe. The benefits are average, maybe slightly below. Vacation time is standard 3 years, but their health plans were getting worse each year by the time I left. They have good work/life balance - standard 8 hour work days, no need to really work overtime or weekends.
featuredReview.cons: The software work is rather mundane. Cafeteria is non-existent. Overall, rather boring company, and many of the most competent engineers leave after a few years. A lot of the middle/upper management have been there for a long time and are set in their ways/capabilities. They're an established player in the credit report market, so they play things safe.

featuredReview.headline: Good Place to work
featuredReview.pros: Diversified workforce, good career opportunities.
featuredReview.cons: Depending on the group, in some groups people have to work 60 hours per week.

featuredReview.headline: Raytheon was a great first job for me
featuredReview.pros: Good salary, interesting projects, tuition reimbursement, lots of young people, a very nice benefits package, ability to move around in the company
featuredReview.cons: I don't have too many negative things to say about Raytheon. I left because I wanted to move back to my home state. My only complaint is that it's a defense job and the funding relies a lot on politics and who's president at the time.

featuredReview.headline: Merciless Cult That Will Bleed You Dry
featuredReview.pros: Great for learning about spine and breaking into the medical device industry. Take everything you can get, then find a better job. Stay two to three years. While you are there, talk about how everything the company culture states has made you a better (fill in the blank).
featuredReview.cons: Management will burden you with blame. A stapler was thrown at the software team when we met in private to ask that claims to shield us from unrealistic timelines be met. (By the way, the impact of the stapler against the white board left a noticeable gouge as evidence). When we reported the incident we were told "don't worry about it." No changes. One individual drank on the job. At a medical device company! People's lives depend on the accuracy of the software. I reported the incidents (plural) and was layed off. I presented pictures I had taken. Call me a snitch, but I don't tolerate that behavior at a medical device company. NuVasive has become a victim of its own culture. I am actually very disappointed.

ceo.name: Greg Lucier
ceo.title: Chairman and Interim Chief Executive Officer

featuredReview.headline: Great Gig, If You Can Get It
featuredReview.pros: MeLLmo is filled with smart people who care about their product and about each other. I've enjoyed my employment a lot and come happy to work every day. Proximity to beach and restaurants is great. Benefits are top-notch.
featuredReview.cons: Like other small-to-medium software companies, they are susceptible to big growing cycles and sometimes, unfortunately, to shrinking cycles. It was sad to go through the later.

featuredReview.headline: It was very good company to work for.
featuredReview.pros: They were easy, expected to get the job done, and offered good benefits.
featuredReview.cons: It was not easy working for some other Managers at times. Because I was on loan they took advantage.

featuredReview.headline: Great company to work for!
featuredReview.pros:
Agile methodologies used to increase project efficiency.

Smart people, Collaborative environment and Great company culture.

Health initiatives taken to make employees more health conscious.

Compressed work week policy enables employees to take alternate Friday off!

Committed leadership.
featuredReview.cons:
No telecommuting allowed.

Benefits are not as competetive.

featuredReview.headline: If new management doesn't mess it all up...
featuredReview.pros: Great, passionate, skilled people, fun working environment, awesome brand and products, CEO is totally cool and inspiring! There are so many great things about this company.
featuredReview.cons: On the consumer software side, there has been an influx of middle managers from Amazon coming on board and we are starting to see some of the negative traits that Amazon is known for - constant fire drills and redirects, little care for employee morale and burnout, and making bold/drastic decisions without taking the time to understand all the elements that should be considered or consulting the people who actually know what's going on. These guys have definitely changed the culture for the worse and slowed us down from getting new products and improvements out. It was a very chaotic environment before the Amazon guys came onboard and got to a critical mass, but it used to be collegial, fun and there was a sense of "we're all building the race car while driving it together". Now it's chaotic and there's a real sense of the employees v. management and the message is "shut up and do what you're told."

featuredReview.headline: Great and Growing
featuredReview.pros:
From top to bottom everyone is well aligned with the company mission and core values--both of which are absolutely sincere.

Work amongst and between teams is cooperative and constructive, not confrontational.  I have experienced nearly zero blame-game or gossip type issues that have been rife other places I have been.  We respect and try to help each other--and that makes day-to-day work exciting rather than a grind.

You are absolutely and always a person first.  I'd almost forgotten what work-life balance meant until coming here.  Everyone genuinely cares that everyone else is doing well not only in their job, but their life.

There's lots of interesting and difficult work to do and problems to solve, but I look forward to coming in and tackling them every day.

There is growth and promotion from within, but will go outside the company when unmet needs emerge.  

To address one of the earlier comments on here: The organization has really grown and matured in the last few years.  People do not need to (and never have that I've seen) conform to some specific personality type.  That said, we do have a lot of fun, but it's a nice balance between energy and professionalism.
featuredReview.cons:
Just the normal things you might expect from a rapidly growing startup.  Catching up on some benefits vs. some larger companies.  But adding while many others are cutting back.

There are some growing pains with adding so many people so fast.  Some processes need revisiting and tuning, and communication is always a challenge in any company--especially one growing so fast.

featuredReview.headline: Work Hard, Play Hard.. I love this place
featuredReview.pros: I've been with MaintenanceNet for several years and I've seen some amazing things. One consistent theme is a company that truly cares about their employees well being. HR is constantly putting together events and treats for the team and individual departments do the same.  Lots of great technologies and leadership is not afraid to pick the best of breed rather than a single product line. This is one of those companies that you will compare all others against!
featuredReview.cons: With the good comes some bad as well. We've been working so fast that things get left by the wayside but we are coming back around and taking care of those issues now.

featuredReview.headline: A once-in-a-lifetime experience
featuredReview.pros: We had some seriously brilliant people, a fun product that we could iterate on rapidly, and a huge user base. There were plenty of interesting problems to solve and openness to solving them with new technologies.
featuredReview.cons: You wind up spending the rest of your career trying to find a job half as good as this one was.

featuredReview.headline: Great Place to work
featuredReview.pros: Flexible hours, comfortable workspace, nice people and work culture
featuredReview.cons: Did not really have any cons

featuredReview.headline: It pays to negotiate hard.
featuredReview.pros: Decent benefits, telecommuting opportunities exist.
featuredReview.cons: Seems we're always having budget problems, so training and development are the first things to get cut. Raises and promotions are handled in a mysterious, mystical fashion; no apparent rhyme or reason; guidelines differ depending on who you talk to. All employees (based on your department) are not treated equal. Senior management is very Command & Control oriented.

featuredReview.headline: Software Test Engineer III
featuredReview.pros: Medical and 401k. Lunch discount.
featuredReview.cons: Promotions, Training, Leadership. Work environment is very bad.

ceo.name: Jun-Ho Cho
ceo.title: President and CEO / Mobile Communications Company

featuredReview.headline: Can be fired at a whim
featuredReview.pros: Friendly environment, worth causes ex. VA projects to contribute to.
featuredReview.cons: Can be fired on a whim. Company [mis]uses Agile agree asks even not knowing or be terminated.

featuredReview.headline: All depends
featuredReview.pros:
Good people and atmosphere, freedom to learn
Balanced work schedule
Decent growth opportunities
featuredReview.cons:
Company has gone through a lot of changes
Lower end of compensation
Stuck in some old ways

featuredReview.headline: A great relaxing place to work..
featuredReview.pros: My fellow employees were great.  Always helpful and fun to be around
featuredReview.cons: Not very forgiving of mistakes.

featuredReview.headline: Was great while it lasted
featuredReview.pros: The environment was great.  There was a lot of talent that was very open and worked very closely together.  It wasn't a huge company so you still had the opportunity to be involved in many aspects of the development life-cycle.  Wonderful growth opportunity.  You always had access to the founding members, and they were all wonderful leaders.
featuredReview.cons: Lack of focus.  PV was cutting edge in the beginning of mobile media, but it seems that it never pushed ahead enough to keep that lead.  After time, the mobile media market was flooded with a large number of players.  At that point PV was juggling a lot of random projects that never really took off.

featuredReview.headline: Good company to work for.
featuredReview.pros: Challenging learning experience.  The company offers ways of training you up into a respected engineer.  Company culture is friendly and people will look out for you.
featuredReview.cons: Times can be tough.  Work can be daunting.  You must be prepared for all challenges.  Sometimes it will take days to complete projects,so you will need to focus harder to get the work done.

ceo.name: James A. Donahue
ceo.title: Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer

featuredReview.headline: Software Engineer
featuredReview.pros: Cutting edge technology, Challenging projects and timelines, ability to work in multiple sub systems and use multiple software thereby increasing your skills rapidly in a short time!
featuredReview.cons: Lately, too much process oriented with more and more documentation required but at the same time too small timelines to complete. Sometimes gets quite hectic to manage depending on how complex and how fast things need to be done.

ceo.name: Robert P. Akins
ceo.title: Chief Technology Strategist of ASML & SVP of Cymer Technologies Division

featuredReview.headline: SDET
featuredReview.pros: Excellent team.  Modern technology.  Lots of potential. Benefits.
featuredReview.cons: None that I can think of.

featuredReview.headline: Good internship, could have been better
featuredReview.pros: Some really nice people, relaxed atmosphere. Everyone was very approachable and willing to help answer questions. My supervisors were awesome, helped me make the most out of my internship. Learned a lot about the way large software projects are developed. Supervisors didn't micro-manage, trusted us to figure things out ourselves.
featuredReview.cons:
Could be good or bad depending on the person: the office culture is a bit older, most employees are in their late 30's to their 50's, so it can be difficult to get to know other people at the office. People at the office were generally very focused on work the entire time, and while everyone was willing to talk about work-related topics, there is very little social energy.

For interns, a job at Bentley Systems is hit or miss: if the project happens to be good, the internship will be an excellent experience and you'll learn a lot. But it also could just be something like code maintenance, which is less valuable. 

Make sure that in an interview you get the details of the project you'll be working on.

featuredReview.headline: Ugg
featuredReview.pros: Location was good.  Hours were good
featuredReview.cons: Lots of yelling and bad internal interaction between developers.  Derry environment

featuredReview.headline: Uncomfortable work environment, Rude owners
featuredReview.pros: Very financially stable company, minimal interruptions to coding, average salary, good benefits.
featuredReview.cons:
The management is rude to employees. The environment is strict, talking is discouraged, no headphones. Developers just write code, and are not part of the design process. The code is crap - a lot of old VB code with dwindling formal structure and a mess of inconsistent patterns. You will not learn good coding practices here. People are fired for strange reasons, one woman was fired on her first day for talking too much.

I agree with everything written in the reviews "Employees are treated like children..." and "Do not recommend unless you do not have any other options"

featuredReview.headline: Great place to be in San Diego
featuredReview.pros: Zeeto has great culture, good work life balance, awesome people and probably some of the best perks in San Diego.
featuredReview.cons: They pay less than market and totally based on how you negotiate. Company is pretty young and direction changes too often.

featuredReview.headline: Great Place
featuredReview.pros: Smart, creative environment with a heavy academic influence -- great place to be an engineer
featuredReview.cons: Open vacation policy sounds great but is rarely practiced by employees, many of whom seem overworked -- it's up to the individual to take advantage of vacations

featuredReview.headline: Great company
featuredReview.pros: Great company, great people. Always have interesting and challenging work. All the brains and talent you can ask for, without the politics, suits and bs!
featuredReview.cons: I don't own my own private jet yet.

featuredReview.headline: A great learning experience in software design, engineering, and maintenance.
featuredReview.pros:
Initial training was detailed and extensive. I was quickly given the opportunity to work on all parts of the software and even start on my own project. I was able to work on something within the software from its conception to its deployment and I was able to see how my contributions made an improvement to our customers' operations. 
The company likes to hire intelligent and creative engineers who have something to offer and also are ready to learn.
featuredReview.cons: Management expects a high level of productivity. Their commitment to every customer's needs demands even more work for the engineers.

featuredReview.headline: Pay seems low, but atmosphere is good.
featuredReview.pros: Management appears to have a sincere interest in making this a comfortable place to work. Work/life balance seems to be stressed.
featuredReview.cons: As someone who started here out of college, it always seems like people getting hired on are getting better compensated. I feel like if someone applied here with my experience they'd pay him/her at least $10k more. That said, I think it's one of the bad traits of the tech industry (or maybe American companies in general?) that the best way to get a raise is to take your experience and work somewhere else.

featuredReview.headline: Good company to start with
featuredReview.pros: Gives opportunity to work in various technology
featuredReview.cons: Offer very less salary to employee

featuredReview.headline: Very good place to work
featuredReview.pros: Very good learning opportunities, good work ethic
featuredReview.cons: Can not think of any cons

featuredReview.headline: Good Company to Work at
featuredReview.pros: A very fantastic startup company which has a very good working environment and has a talented team. These guys are young, but appears very professional. Everybody is responsive and energetic.
featuredReview.cons: There can be more communications between different departments, for example, the engineer team and the sales team or the marketing team. Also hope there will be more options for the Friday Pizza.

featuredReview.headline: Happy Camper
featuredReview.pros: Relaxed work environment. Engaged CEO. Small company feel. Wide variety of projects with small teams, so you get to try a lot of stuff. Very "open source" friendly, both in use and under production (or at least as close to "open source" as DoD software can get).
featuredReview.cons: If you're looking to be more than a team lead, you're not going to find a big enough organization to lead here. A fair amount of software has an experimental feel to it, which makes sense, nothing is developed for retail consumers. ...and about 10k calories worth of snack foods are there to tempt you all day long.

featuredReview.headline: Too much stress and pressur
featuredReview.pros: Free bananas in the kitchen.
featuredReview.cons: Extremely cheap company. Nickle and dime everything. 4 people per cube. Very hostile environment. No respect to employees. No sick days. Traffic is bad to commute Carlsbad office.

featuredReview.headline: Great Work-Life Balance Job
featuredReview.pros:
- Great work-life balance.
- Best Location to work.
- Stable job. People are working from long time so less chances of layoff.
- Company growth is good. Every year good bonus sharing.
- Flexible in time. HR Team is supportive.
- Managers are supportive and provide enough time for work-life balance.
- Acquiring new companies and expanding business which is good sign of growth.
- Benefits are good compare to other mid level companies.
- Easy to work with team members and other colleagues.
featuredReview.cons: Nothing major for this section.

featuredReview.headline: Great idea, talented people, questionable execution
featuredReview.pros: They have a great mission and offer great benefits. Location and views from the office can't be beat. Employees are all talented and are excellent coworkers.
featuredReview.cons: Although the mission of the organization is well defined, project goals and prototypes (this is a non-profit, therefore, all "products" are referred to as prototypes) can and often change. You can possibly end up working on a different project or have yours canceled. This may leave you looking for a new position, but they are helpful in doing this.

featuredReview.headline: Good Company
featuredReview.pros: Good company with good people in most areas. The other people at company are are helpful and work with you. There are opportunities to learn new things and move up.
featuredReview.cons: In the process of fixing old process. Some changes leave people confused, but we figure it out. The building and some tools are not so new. We are moving to bigger building soon.

featuredReview.headline: business is business, the bottom line
featuredReview.pros: decent company, but a bunch of software programmers and some lawyers
featuredReview.cons: not much job security for a long term career unless you make it in to the elite upper level of core management.

featuredReview.headline: very good and flexible place
featuredReview.pros:
good facility
good food
good people
good managers
many courses
flexible work form home
featuredReview.cons: not too much possibility to be promoted or change teams or departments. salaries do not get up very much each year

ceo.name: Sehat Sutardja
ceo.title: President, CEO, and Director; President and CEO, Marvell Semiconductor

featuredReview.headline: IT much improved
featuredReview.pros:
Lots of opportunities for people with the talent in IT (it's primarily a Java/MSSQL shop).

CSA has shifted rapidly away from dated technologies to a strong SOA based architecture.  The IT problems listed on here from a couple years ago before I joined have been purged or left behind.  Good team, almost no turnover in the last couple years.  Huge business partners that bring big volume and technical challenges.
featuredReview.cons:
The business is complicated.  As others have mentioned, new people have a lot to learn in the first year.  You really can't just code, you need to understand the business as well.

Moving to a new office next year, no more panoramic canyon view.

featuredReview.headline: Good Place to work with lot of benifits
featuredReview.pros:
1)Good Place to work
2)Good pay
3)Life and work balance
4)very nice people
5)Nice benefits
6)Lot of work if you are dedicated
featuredReview.cons:
1) HR sucks . They dont wana do anything else sitting and doing nothing
2)Upper management needs to know how to make profit
3) Consultants remain like full time employees 
4) Lot of politics

featuredReview.headline: Interesting work and unique challenges
featuredReview.pros:
Great products and technology.
Many bright colleagues in both engineering and management. (very good stud/dud ratio)
A great place to gain domain knowledge and cross-train if you are inclined.
featuredReview.cons: Overly complicated and indirect management. What exactly are all these people doing?

featuredReview.headline: Covidien, A Medical Device Leader
featuredReview.pros: Good Salary, Good Benefits, Chances of promotion.
featuredReview.cons: Too much uncertainty, no loyalty with employees.

featuredReview.headline: A company that truly respects and appreciates your contributions
featuredReview.pros: The best thing from my own experience, is that they don't micro-manage you.  They hire you to do the job and don't feel the need to hover over you to ensure you get it done.  They provide a friendly open environment where everyone works together, without a defined hierarchy.  You are treated as an equal by everyone, regardless of the initials that follow their name.  They strive to provide a relaxed atmosphere and grant employees opportunities to have fun with their co-workers, whether it be at the weekly on site happy hours, to the amenities like, pool table, shuffleboard and Foosball or the full gym and basketball court.  I also like the relaxed dress code.
featuredReview.cons: Honestly, I haven't found any.  I'll update my review should I stumble across something later.

featuredReview.headline: Pay me!
featuredReview.pros: Pros? No way! I don't understand how do you have an award for best staffing companny
featuredReview.cons: I left this company last week. They were supposed to pay me in my last day of work but obviously it did not happen. Tried to contact people to see if there is any problem but nobody answers me phone calls neither emails.

featuredReview.headline: First company after college
featuredReview.pros: Big Corporation, with benefits.  Raises every year.
featuredReview.cons: No cons that I can speak of

featuredReview.headline: software developer
featuredReview.pros: Best in salary when compared to other Indian based service company
featuredReview.cons: There is not much of cons in I felt in this company

featuredReview.headline: Good People - Frustrating Company
featuredReview.pros:
I worked with and learned from many good people at this company. The pay is above average. 
Always work so you will never be bored. Great opportunity to grow.
featuredReview.cons: Huge cultural divide between FTE and contract positions. They admittedly have a culture of 'public flogging'. They expect you to jump in with little or no introduction to LPL's process, or even where to locate access, documents, etc. Very unrealistic project expectations which caused many projects to be canceled mid-flight, or to release no fully scoped.

featuredReview.headline: Work
featuredReview.pros:
Flexible Schedule
Friendly Staff
Work with latest coding technologies
featuredReview.cons: Old legacy code can be difficult to understand/maintain.

featuredReview.headline: Senior Software Engineer
featuredReview.pros: Fantastic Compensation & Benefits. You are treated wonderfully. I love going to work everyday. The work is challenging which I consider to be a good thing.
featuredReview.cons: The products being made aren't the most exciting things to be working on. Sometimes, there are decisions made without consultation of the team which leads to people being 'out of the loop'.

featuredReview.headline: Beware!!
featuredReview.pros: The development groups outside of San Diego are great and know their stuff, and are largely left alone by the toxic nature of the San Diego development group.
featuredReview.cons:
Tapestry is actually comprised of 4 different companies that were consolidated through purchases by Boeing.  The legacy company is located in San Diego and has been merged with a troubled company while the other remote offices have been largely left as is. 


The tapestry legacy company has largely given up after the forced purchase of a failing company and that failing company's culture has taken over the San Diego group.  A large portion of the tapestry leadership was replaced with these executives and/or Boeing shills.  Most of the legacy employees either have already left or are planning on leaving. 

The failing software group is reluctant to change and are they still learning how to do basic things such as how to commit code and come up with basic QA controls.  The company claims the have been doing this for 20 years but is still working through procedures that startups solve their first year. 

The technical leadership in the group is detached and doesn't understand their product and customers.  Much of their decisions seem to be driven off of the latest fad technologies and not off of a real need for those technologies.  Developers are constantly talked down to, lectured, and thrown under the bus when executing ill conceived ideas given to them by the technical leadership. Unfortunately if anyone offers an alternative opinion to what is being promoted , their reputation will be destroyed and they find that you are no longer included in any technical discussions.  Most of the technical group has left for other opportunities because of the poor treatment and lack of proper leadership.

Program management is concerned only about schedule, even if that means delivering a non working product and/or one that does not meet the requirements of their customers.  This has led to a lot of quality issues which will cost double the original development costs to fix.  They claim they are interested in changing, but when it comes down to execution they fail miserably. 

Since the last acquisition, raises and bonuses are non existent.  The bonus and compensation structures are built based upon unrealistic long range business plans made up by a business development group that doesn't even understand what they are selling. The company makes employees feel as if it is their fault that they are not meeting these goals which leads to even worse morale.

featuredReview.headline: Great place to be an engineer
featuredReview.pros:
Get the freedom to design and get your hands dirty. 
Everyone wears many hats at this company, I learned a lot of new skills working at Vulcan.
Competitive compensation.
Reasonable benefits.
featuredReview.cons:
There is little freedom to work from home.
Poor project estimation processes in place often result in schedule hardships.

featuredReview.headline: Senior Software Engineer
featuredReview.pros:
Great company
Nice work culture
Good benefits
featuredReview.cons: Difficult to hard core development roles.

featuredReview.headline: software engineer
featuredReview.pros: Manager and co workers are very helpful and good company if you want to build your carrier in security.
featuredReview.cons: very small team, so not to much to discuss.

featuredReview.headline: decent consulting company.
featuredReview.pros: very supportive for their employees
featuredReview.cons: small company. no tech training program.

featuredReview.headline: Nice people, bad management
featuredReview.pros: Nice colleagues, sharing of knowledge. Flexible work hours and respect for each other. No trouble makers, atleast among the engineers.
featuredReview.cons: Sr Mgmt has no respect for the engineers. There is no direction and maturity of projects.

featuredReview.headline: Great company
featuredReview.pros:
Profitable company
Great people
Great management
Cares for people
featuredReview.cons: Nothing I can think of

featuredReview.headline: Senior Software Engineer
featuredReview.pros: Good benefits.  Subsidized cafeteria.  Looks good on a resume.
featuredReview.cons: Constant reorgs.  No clear direction.

featuredReview.headline: TechFlow is not a real company.  It is a scam of a group of subcontractors who do subcontract for bigger company.
featuredReview.pros: Interview and hire in one day.
featuredReview.cons:
Don't expect that the company will employ you as the employee.  They will dispose or laid off you anytime.  
I was interviewed and hired within one day, and after 4 weeks working there, they called the entire group of 8 developers, I am one of them :), to the office, drink a coke, then received laid off notice.  When we return to our table, the computer was locked. They told us that we have 10 minutes to clean up table and pack our belong and out.

featuredReview.headline: Decent place to work
featuredReview.pros: Compensation is great. I learned a lot
featuredReview.cons: I didn't find any cons.

featuredReview.headline: Only as your last resort
featuredReview.pros:
- Base salary is acceptable although lower than the competition.
- Two months initial paid training if just out of college.
- Opportunity to try multiple locations and roles.
featuredReview.cons:
- Lack of communication. My HR, RMG, Supervisor changes all the time.
- Company overstates the number of positions available.
- Company seems to give preference to expats over US locals.
- Company promises many things to employees, such as relocation pay but doesn't deliver.
- Company internal processes are convoluted and highly complicated.
- They never seem to have a position where you are.
- Company expects you to perform duties that are not going to help you gain any experience.
- Be ready to be disposable.
- I was told by one client : "Obviously this job is not important to us that's why we are contracting it out".
- Had to move out of state for only 7 months to be told there's nothing else for you here.

featuredReview.headline: .Net Developer
featuredReview.pros: Great Work environment, culture
featuredReview.cons: May be salary thinking you are living in California

featuredReview.headline: Developers need not apply
featuredReview.pros:
I worked with a good group of people - that are leaving day by day.
23 days off per year is nice
featuredReview.cons:
Code base – spaghetti code would be a compliment. And you will not be allowed to refactor any of it unless the task to refactor it has been approved by the Product team… who are too busy throwing new features in to worry about how unmanageable the code has become. 

Offshore – there may be diamonds in that rough, but they soon move on. Every bug fix or design change is met with argument and resistance by their lead structure, and the code they produce is unworkable. But there is no way for the onshore component to impact the offshore crew, so there is no consequence to their actions. 

Scrum – yes, they say they are an Agile shop. However, the beginning of each Sprint consists of a 4-6 hour meeting where you are told what you will be doing for the next two weeks, then asked to point and estimate. Why bother when you told us what we have to have done? I have literally been told “you have to get these “n” tasks done in the next two weeks, how long do you think it will take you?” 

Cooperation – over the past few years a wall has been built between the team that develops the product and the team that supports it; to the point where I was reprimanded for speaking to the support team. They are the people directly dealing with the customers and the development team is not allowed to ask them about the customer’s views on the product. 

Medical Benefits – to call them benefits is a joke. You would think that working for a health care company they would take care of you, but it’s the opposite. The worst health plan I have had in my career. High deductible (over $4,000) before *any* coverage kicks in. Co-pay? Nope, all office visits are 100% on you until you reach your deductible, then they cover a percentage. And for that you pay upwards of $300 a month to insure your family. Yes, you read that right - $300 a month for the right to pay the first $4K. Every year we are given a survey to fill out… every year the health insurance is rated at a 1 (lowest possible)… and every year it gets worse; higher deductible, higher monthly, etc.

Pay – expect an annual review under 2%. Not sour grapes of a poor employee… everyone gets the same raise regardless of if you are a rock star or just a rock. I guess they don’t think employees talk to each other.

I worked with a few excellent people here; most of whom have either left the company or are looking to leave. Other than that I cannot think of one redeeming factor this place has to offer.  I had to give it one star because zero was not an option.

featuredReview.headline: Fun place to work.  Though must be meticulous with time-keeping.
featuredReview.pros:
Fun atmosphere.  Easy to get along with all the employees.  As a contracting house, the work stays new and fresh and varies every few months.

Always someone around to ask questions or advice.

Gave very much autonomy for weekly tasks to get done. Sometimes too much so.
featuredReview.cons:
Require meticulous time-tracking for each task.  Which means each indivitual task must be worked on, logged, and stopped before changing focus.  Which is to be expected as they are billing clients for time.  

Training was more or less non-existant.  But practises were easily enough to pick up.

Salary is a bit low; but not terribly out-of-band.

featuredReview.headline: Very Trustworthy company to work with.....Great environment and Great management
featuredReview.pros:
Great recruitment team to find you job in no time, Great compensation on time without failure, Helps you in your good and bad time..

They are open to talk and no hidden agenda. Good Management.
featuredReview.cons: Optional benefits i.e. health insurance leave a bit to be desired..

featuredReview.headline: A good experience overall.
featuredReview.pros: Good execution, good salary, international team.
featuredReview.cons: Lack of focus, constant change, taking too much risks with huge acquisitions.

featuredReview.headline: Great company, bad management
featuredReview.pros: Company has innovative ideas and the working environment is great.  Great benefits compared to other San Diego based companies which were cutting a majority of their health plans.
featuredReview.cons: Terrible management, with infighting between department VPs.  Hubris runs rampant out of the Redwood City office. Poor communication to their employees. Attempt at expanding too quickly and placing all their eggs in one basket (Defiance) led to a rapid downfall in San Diego. One successful title does not make Hartsman the savior of the company.  Watch the company dwindle to nothing as the investors attempt to recoup their losses.

featuredReview.headline: Software Engineer
featuredReview.pros: I feel very comfortable and I love it
featuredReview.cons: I need to move to another place with my families.

featuredReview.headline: I worked at Metron in San Diego, CA
featuredReview.pros: I did learn a lot about the industry.
featuredReview.cons: I am now on my third job as a software engineer and I can honestly say that the work environment was too uptight at Metron. I currently work for a company with strict deadlines but we still manage to keep it light and fun when it comes to office relationships. Many times I though management was rude, but I just kept silent and looked for other opportunities that had a better work environment.

featuredReview.headline: Nice place to work overall
featuredReview.pros: Th San Diego office is brand new.  Brand new building and everything. Free snacks, flexible hours. You work on the cutting edge of threat intelligence which is really neat.  So you are always learning something new.  In addition, the team is fairly tight with a number of people who are friends outside of work.
featuredReview.cons:
My biggest complaint would probably be the lack of recognition.  I think lots of places are like this.  You get a lot of attention if something is going wrong but no mention of success with a bigger project releasing.
I think like most companies I have been with, agile is kind of a mess.  Scrum teams are more defined by your skillset rather than project.  So you might be working with people from other teams that are not part of your scrum team.
One other thing I have noticed, there doesn't seem to be room for promotions or at least the worker bee types do not seem to move up the chain often.

featuredReview.headline: Great first job
featuredReview.pros: very little administrative overhead; great ability to expand your software knowledge; learn about software escrow; position gives you a true sense of pecking order in the field.
